indicators.justification:
Open data is available on expenses and budget, the data used by the Ministry of Finance is fed by all government agencies that are obliged to carry out payment transactions to suppliers, it has enough information to make available to the public, however, The open data provided by the Ministry of Finance (SEFIN) is not very easy to use.
The data held in the Financial Administration System (SIAFI) does not have interconnection with other systems of government entities, due to computer security decisions. This limits the link between financial data with any other system that requires a link and have better information.

indicators.justification:
The sworn statement submitted by public officials to the TSC allows the data of the public servant to be recorded in order to verify their assets and make cross-checks with other sources of information such as that of the financial system. However, in practice, public servants sometimes do not declare all their assets and liabilities. In short, the TSC does not have a true and effective mechanism for verifying and monitoring said declarations. Although there is a computer system, it is not used by the TSC and the affidavits are on paper, stored and vulnerable to theft and destruction. In the current conditions, the affidavits only represent an input to be used in the case of some investigation in the future.
In the respective institutions the link to the compensation of employees, only the list of positions, positions and salaries of personnel with active appointment in the ministerial masks appear, from the position of Minister to those of lower hierarchy; but the payroll of the personnel of the Armed Forces or the National Police does not appear.

indicators.justification:
Notwithstanding the provisions of the State Contracting Law in relation to publications, all contractor selection procedures and contracts entered into must be disclosed in the HonduCompras system that is administered by ONCAE.

The ONCAE has open data on the purchasing processes available in its portal, although the information can be downloaded in Excel by year of execution, these data are divided into several worksheets and it is difficult to make confinements for the search for information .

indicators.justification:
Given that the government does not have a budget to implement open data in government institutions, in order to promote this issue, support from international donors has been important to carry out some initiatives. The World Bank (1) has been the main promoter of open data in Honduras, carrying out different actions in the training, technical advice and financing of events in favor of open data.

indicators.justification:
Municipal governments do not have open data, however, there is the Association of Municipalities of Honduras (AMHON) (1) that manages agreements with other government institutions where they exchange data, but they do not have the characteristics of open data. There are no regulations that oblige local governments to implement open data, in addition to this, few municipalities have the technological capabilities, trained personnel and resources to make open data available. They publish data in the national transparency portal.

indicators.justification:
Different public institutions have promoted training on the subject of data, the Secretariat of Transparency (1) has led the training of public officials with the Diploma of Open Data and Public Information. However, other institutions such as the INE (2), the IAIP (3),  and the High Management School (4)carry out different training sessions, in which they include the subject of data.
There are trainings by private universities, seeing the need for the Government to continue training public employees on specific issues, for example UNITEC develops training focused on public administration.

indicators.justification: There is no interoperability between the different institutions that use open data in Honduras, much less in other areas that only provide information without considering open data such as private companies. Data is not shared from one institution to another sometimes due to lack of interest, other times due to lack of technical capacity and also due to lack of political will.

indicators.justification:
In Honduras, there is currently no law in force that regulates the protection of personal data (1). However, efforts have been made in this regard. In 2015, a bill for the Protection of Personal Data was promoted by the then in the National Congress. This project was based on the preliminary project that was presented by the National Institute for Access to Public Information in 2013 with the support of the Spanish Agency for International Development Cooperation (AECID).
Currently, the bill is still under debate in the legislative chamber. The last debate took place in April 2018. However, this process has been delayed more than expected, considering that only 19 of the 97 articles contained in the project have been approved.
In the absence of special legislation, personal data in Honduras have at least one protection that is recognized in the Law of the Institute of Access to Public Information, Legislative Decree No. 170 - 2006. In articles 24 to 26 of this law Habeas Data, the protection of personal data, is recognized and the figure of the National Human Rights Commissioner is presented as an office empowered to initiate actions for the protection of personal data; It also establishes a prohibition in which no person can request other personnel who may generate some type of discrimination or put at risk the moral and patrimonial rights of that individual.

## Sources:
1)https://fra1.digitaloceanspaces.com/

indicators.justification:
In Honduras, the Ministry of Finance has absolute control of the income and expenditures of public finances of government institutions, including local governments, since it makes the disbursements of some budget items.

There are laws, regulations, guides that offer a complete base to collect and publish financial data, however, the issue of "structured data" is very ambiguous since it is not tacitly exposed in the regulations, but is implicitly defined as "tables" which are relatively text-type files that usually display in rows and columns with titles (2).

indicators.justification:
The Organic Law of the Superior Court of Accounts (TSC) is clear in the scope and procedures in the rendering of accounts of public officials, with the limitation of not being able to publish the personal data of them and their family nucleus. Regarding the publication of the patrimonial declaration and verification of compliance, according to the regulations, the TSC must keep absolute confidentiality regarding the content of the declarations, documents and investigations that are carried out for purposes other than those provided for in the Law.
The TSC lacks a financial or asset investigation manual; as well as a specialization program for its auditors in matters of law, forensic audits or criminal investigation techniques. In addition to this, it was learned that the TSC does not carry out informal verifications of the sworn statements that public servants present, but only when it is investigated based on a complaint.
There is a need to optimize the systems for analyzing the content of the declarations, and to adopt measures so that they also serve as a useful tool for the detection and prevention of conflicts of interest, in addition to their use as an instrument to detect possible cases of illicit.

indicators.justification:
The law (1) applies to those who participate in the elections of the central government, municipal and deputies. The parameters to be followed with the accountability of those who participate in popular elections are well defined. In addition to the regulations, there is also the Honduras Accountability Platform (2) is an initiative that seeks to promote transparency regarding the financing of electoral campaigns, as well as help Obliged Subjects to make their income declarations and expenses, this platform is sponsored by UNDP.
Despite the approval of a new legal framework and a Clean Policy Unit, efforts to regulate the contributions received by political parties come up against restrictions that prevent knowing who the private contributors are and taking actions in the interests of transparency and accountability. accounts.

indicators.justification:
Honduran legislation on freedom of thought, expression and peaceful demonstration is not new, nor is the operation of a regulatory entity for the allocation and control of telecommunications, so that the shortcomings are due to institutional negligence, abuse and misrepresentation in the application of the rules and controls, for interests outside the common good and the community interest.

The Law of Transparency and Access to Information, It is a legal tool that gives citizens access to topics of interest, it is most used by journalists and civil society organizations to obtain information on government management.

Sources:
Law of Transparency and Access to Information (https://www.tsc.gob.hn/biblioteca/index.php/leyes/17-ley-de-transparencia-y-acceso-a-la-informacion-publica)
MANUAL OF NORMS AND GENERAL GUIDELINES (SIELHO) (https://sielho.iaip.gob.hn/static/docs/manual_oip.pdf)

evidence.title: Law of Transparency and Access to Information
MANUAL OF NORMS AND GENERAL GUIDELINES (SIELHO)

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The framework covers the entire public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the framework assessed for this question?

indicators.justification: In the search for information, results showed that the private company does not apply open data for products or services on due diligence.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of such products or services in the country.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data

indicators.justification:
The use of land data has generated high representation of the relevant actors, including the sub-national level and ensuring gender equity, as well as the inclusion of indigenous peoples and Afro-descendants, according to the Final Evaluation of the Project Support for the Preparation for the Reducing Emissions Due to Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD +) in Honduras (1) sponsored by UNDP.
It has also promoted the generation of land policies, strengthening criteria according to published data. (2, 3,4 and 5)

## Sources:
1)https://www.forestcarbonpartnership.org/system/files/documents/Final%20evaluation%20REDD%2B%20Honduras_Spanish.pdf
2)https://costhonduras.hn/2019/10/28/bases-de-datos-abiertos-alertaran-riesgos-ambientales-en-obras-de-infraestructura/
3)https://www.sica.int/documentos/serie-conservacion-en-tierras-privadas-propuesta-de-normativa-para-la-conservacion-de-tierras-privadas-en-honduras-relacionadas-con-el-proyecto-de-ley-forestal-de-las-areas-protegidas-y-la-vida-silvestre-en-discusion-en-tercer-debate-en-el-cong_1_9068.html
4)http://www.miambiente.gob.hn/blog/view/mi-ambiente-presento-documento-final-de-la-estrategia-nacional-redd
5)https://www.forestcarbonpartnership.org/system/files/documents/Final%20evaluation%20REDD%2B%20Honduras_Spanish.pdf

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
Is there evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts on land policy?

indicators.justification:
Organized civil society and the media are the actors that most use integrity data, however, the information published by public entities is not totally reliable.

For example, in most of the platforms used by the government of Honduras through the different public institutions, some lack modules of the required processes or data. In other cases, the platforms are at the expense of public officials who, according to their criteria, upload the data they want to upload, as there are no entities to verify the quality of the information.

## Sources:
1)https://www.cna.hn/revista-anticorrupcion/
2)http://biblioteca.asjhonduras.com/

6)https://proceso.hn/cohep-e-iaip-firman-memorandum-de-entendimiento-de-transparentar-proceso-electoral/

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
Currently, public purchases in Honduras have two accesses to open data, the first one that is directly linked to the portal of the State Contracting and Procurement Regulations Office (ONCAE) (1) has a basic structure where it is in spreadsheets and the data in a global way, this prevents the interested party to have the information they are looking for, they have to organize the data on their own.
On the other hand, there is another open contracting website (2), which is more dynamic, user-friendly and easy to search, and the data can be reused under international standards.

## Sources:
1)https://oncae.gob.hn/datosabiertos
2)https://www.contratacionesabiertas.gob.hn/

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
